translated: Jātaka
Dvādasakanipāta
Cūḷakuṇālavagga
. Kāmajātaka

analyzed: kāmam kāmayamānassa  tassa ce tam samijjhati
translated: “One who desires what is desirable,🔽if he succeeds in getting it,
is certainly delighted in mind,
having obtained what he wanted.
One who desires what is desirable,
if he succeeds in getting it,
then he seeks other sensual pleasures,
like a thirsty man who finds water.
Just as the horn of a bull grows
along with the growth of the bull,🔽so too for a foolish, ignorant man,
who is not discerning,
thirst and craving grow
along with his growth.🔽Rice and barley, cattle and horses,
slaves and human beings,

analyzed: da tvā ca na alam ekassa
translated: having given all this to one person,
the wise one should act equally.

analyzed: rājā pasayha pathavim vijitvā  sa sāgarantam
translated: Having conquered the earth by force,
and ruled over the land with its ocean,🔽being dissatisfied with the near shore,
he should seek the far shore of the ocean.
As long as one remembers sensual pleasures,
the mind does not find satisfaction;
having turned back and seen this,

original: Te ve sutittā ye paññāya tittā.
analyzed: te ve su tittā ye paññāya tittā
translated: they are truly satisfied who are satisfied with wisdom.
The best of men is satisfied with wisdom,
He is not tormented by sensual pleasures.
The man who is satisfied with wisdom,
Craving does not hold him in its power.
He should abandon sensual pleasures,
The one of little desire, the one without greed.
The man who is restrained in regard to sensual pleasures,
He is not tormented by sensual pleasures.

original: Rathakārova cammassa,🔽parikantaṁ upāhanaṁ;🔽Yaṁ yaṁ cajati kāmānaṁ,
analyzed: rathakāraḥ uva cammassa  parikantam upāhana  yam yam cajati
translated: Just as a chariot-maker,🔽Having heated and stretched the leather,🔽Whatever sensual pleasures he abandons,
That much happiness is produced for him;
If he desires all happiness,
He should abandon all sensual pleasures.”
“Eight verses have been spoken by you,
All of them are meaningful.
Accept them, Great Brahmā,
This is what you have said.”
“I have no use for thousands,
Or hundreds or millions.
For the last verse that you have spoken,
My mind is not delighted with sensual pleasures.”
“This young man is indeed excellent,🔽The sage who knows all the worlds,
The wise one who fully understands
Craving, the mother of suffering.”
The Birth Story of Kāma, the fourth.
